description.text:
Created through a 2D simulation of reaction diffusion extruded through time. The top of the model is t=0.
Designed in Processing and printed on a Makerbot replicator
Print!

title: 10' Spell Radius
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a spell template for tabletop games like Pathfinder or Dungeons and Dragons.  It helps you to quickly define areas which are affected by spells.  You can use it to keep track of persistent effects, or to target new ones.  I find that it really speeds up my sessions.
This thing was modelled in Sketchup and converted to .stl by a plugin, so the geometry is likely imperfect.  It was printed at a 0.2 mm layer height on a Printrbot LC.

title: Enlarge Person Platform
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a 2'x2' platform designed to represent the "Enlarge Person" spell found in many tabletop roleplaying games.  It includes a hollow for the miniature as well as compatibility with my "stackable effect square" design, making it easy to see and easy to move.

This thing was designed in Sketchup and converted to a stereo-lithography file using a third-party plugin, so the geometry is likely imperfect.  I printed it in PLA using a 0.2 mm layer height on a Printrbot LC, then painted it with a single coat of primer and a coat of green paint.  
Be careful with the inner ridges, as they are the most fragile part of the design and can bend or warp if roughly used.  Effect squares should fit loosely on top of the platform after the paint (optional) has been applied.

I printed Zaggo's whistle twice as big in PLA and it works!

comments.text: I was amazed to see the top (bridges) of this whistle extrude with no problems at all (although I had problems elsewhere, but that's just due to a filament jam). PLA, 195C at bridge layer with a 40cm fan to cool freshly extruded material. It drew out perfectly, I nearly had a heart attach watching that part! I did drop 1 strand on the first layer, but the rest were solid and no noticeable sag. 4 hours 13 mins tho!
comments.author: jcaywood

comments.text: i can think of an awesome vacuumcleaner Prank when i see this one..
comments.author: yzorg

comments.text: How do you get PLA to print large gaps without having that layer droop down?
comments.author: CidVilas

comments.text: I was expecting the PLA to droop down as well. It does a little when closing the gap the first layer, but with the second layer on top of that it is almost flat. In total the side contains about 7 layers, so it fills up completely. I think the PLA should not be too hot for this layer, that helps a lot.
comments.author: CidVilas

comments.text: That's just asking for a picture of it being blown! :-) (Then to try one 3x size...)
comments.author: Lenbok

comments.text: Just uploaded a few!
comments.author: Lenbok

comments.text: Now that's what I call a whistle!! Is its pitch much lower? I'd love to blow your whistle when I'm in Utrecht again (not figuratively speaking)
comments.author: siertwijnia

comments.text: Yes, the pitch is indeed much lower. It consumes quite a lot of air. Also the ball is to heavy to get rolling by whistling.... But hey, nice experiment though ;-)

description.text:
This is the radio you first see before you black out and get taken to The Sierra Madre. In Dead Money for Fallout New Vegas.
It is close, i drew it from just a screen capture of the front. I could play the game again and get it much closer, but will have to wait and see.
UPDATE: I relooked at my CAD file and noticed it was not curvy enough for a 50's style radio, so I softened a bunch of edges. Radio_v2.stl should be more realistic.

I have not printed this yet, since I drew it to scale which is about 12" tall.
The uploaded file is much much smaller. Scale it to how you feel. Use about 10%-20% infill. You might need some support

comments.text: This was drawn to copy this radio http://static2.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20120827224806/fallout/images/d/d2/SM_radio.jpg. And the game is set in the 1950's style. I am into older radios as well. But you could let the developers of the game know their mistake.

description.text: I wanted something to wear to show the world that I was a 3D printer enthusiast, so I created this pin to wear on my shirt.  I bought some pin clasps from Hobby Lobby that had adhesive built in and attached it to the back.  I am printing a two color one right now and I hope to post pictures of it soon.
Using 123D Design I used the text primitive and intersected the two main parts.  A THREE and a DEE and then subtracted the areas that didn't intersect.

author: richbarton59

description.text: A parametric model for mounting glass and heated bed to a printer. It was intended for the Rostock, but I suppose it can work on any stationary-bed printer with enough space to accommodate the bit of extra width off the corners.

This piece is completely parametric. Dimensions include:
-Hotbed height off of mounting platform
-Thickness of glass
-Side length of hotbed
-Side length of glass
-Bolt size
-Bolt bore (Depth, diameter, distance from edge)
-Bracket side length
-Thickness above glass In the code you can also change the number of bolt holes (Not really necessary though) Just open the SCAD file and enter the variables you need. It's already set to be used with M3 bolts on the Rostock using heated bed and glass sourced from makergear.com.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/3M04T9cT4JI

title: Printrbot Jr v2 Bed Leveling Nut Holder

description.text: I got tired of trying to use three hands to level my print bed.  One for the allen wrench, one for the box wrench, and one for the piece of paper.  So I designed and printed these parts to prevent the nuts from turning so that I only had to use an allen wrench and a piece of paper.

I printed using PLA.  You'll need two of the front and one each of the back left and back right.  The back are different as there has to be clearance for the bed AND the base.  Firmly press them in place with the lip up towards the bed (this is what prevents the nuts from turning).

author: jeromedayton

description.text:
My cat refuses to drink from anything still such as plate or a cup.
So I catch it licking the faucet for any drop there is.
Since, I've been leaving a small drip just so my cat can drink.
Now, to speed the process up I've created this little collector. It fits standard 10 mm radius faucet nozzle.
No support needed

I'd rather set up a fountain - just saying

comments.text: Sorry for asking, but, isn't it toxic or just when it is melted?
comments.author: williamk

comments.text: nah, PLA is corn based product and is safe.
comments.author: williamk

comments.text: I think what williamk means is that if you use a brass nozzle toxins could leach into the plastic part you are printing. If you are however using a stainless steel nozzle and have never run plastics that can be harmful such as ABS through it then you should be okay except for one little thing... bacteria. You see, plastic printed from a 3D printer is rather porous and as such can be a breeding ground for bacteria.
comments.author: secretgspot

comments.text: Considering the places from which pets will otherwise drink their water, it seems like the possible bacteria collected from running faucet water is very little to be concerned about.

I wanted to model a building from Lidar data so I figure why not go big. Although far from the largest house in the world, William Randolph Hearst's San Simeon definately qualifies as ridiculously huge. How big is it? About the square footage of a typical Walmart. Here is my video tutorial showing how to make 3d prints from Lidar https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t4-ICkvyJv0 Complete instructions on how to make models from digital elevation data can be found on my blog at http://www.the3dprintedfuture.com/shapespeare/?p=1 An interesting artifact of the Lidar scan seems to have turned all the iconic queen palm trees into pine trees. I made it from a LIDAR dataset collected to study fault lines affecting Diablo Canyon Nuclear Power Plant and made available on http://opentopo.sdsc.edu/. The LIDAR point cloud was gridded to a 0.5m resolution.

comments.text:
Hi mate great job on this. If i wanted to make a model of my fathers home town of Dubrovnik in Croatia as a gift for his next birthday, can you advise on this? I have a home made Delta (mini me to gigantor) but wouldn't know where to even find a file or how to convert from other data.
I have spent more time designing my own items like a quirky lego variant or a 3 volt incandescent bulb to LED converter so all the old torches in the world don't go to land fill.
comments.author: ZInk

comments.text: I looked around a bit but I can't find LIDAR data for Dubrovnik.  In the US many of these surveys are made with public funding so the results are made available to the public.  The rest of the world is often not so open.  The best data you can find worldwide is the SRTM data shot by the space shuttle, but it is not very detailed and would probably produce a disappointing map.
comments.author: ZInk

comments.text: Love these Lidar models. I featured your work on my website. http://www.3dphobbyist.com/lidar-data-creates-beautiful-3d-printed-topographic-maps/ Keep them coming!
comments.author: 3DPHobbyist

comments.text: These LIDAR based models are absolutely amazing!

comments.text: Amazing detail!

remixed_from.author: xkriva11
remixed_from.title: Printrbot Simple Y axis string tensioner

description.text:
Do you own a Printrbot Simple?  Have you had x-axis slippage and have struggled to get the x-axis fishing line on there REALLY tight?  Well, this simple belt tensioner can help in some cases.  
Simply download, print and snake the fishing line through the gaps in the serpentine.  This will add just enough tension to resolve the slippage when the bot moves from one extreme to the next when starting the next layer.  
One picture shows the before tensioned part right next to the part AFTER the tensioner was installed.  The other photo tries to illustrate where the tensioner is applied.

Simply searched around on Thingiverse and became inspired by the referenced things. I've also seen a similar belt tensioner on the TypeAMachines Series 1. But to install it on your Printrbot Simple you:
1) Get your fishing line belt as tight as you can get it.
2) Then, print out this part (it will still print at slower speeds with decent results as there are not accelerations large enough to cause the x-axis to slip.
3) Weave the belt in between the gaps in the serpentine part; making sure you keep the belt inside the gaps and that the piece is as close to the nuts holding the fishing wire as possible (otherwise the piece will possibly get sucked into the motor axis--not good).
4) Start printing nice and clean parts!

comments.text: this is brilliant! I have found that calibration can be greatly affected by the tension on the belts. If they are too loose the printer won't necessarily lose its position, but circles will be lemon shaped from irregularities in the sandpaper pullies
comments.author: nt86
